title: Oceanic Guide
summary:
This guide walks you step by step through a realistic oceanic flight on the IVAO network, from planning to oceanic exit.

This is not a rulebook to memorize, it is a guide to know what to do, when to do it, and why it matters.
content:

This is not a rulebook to memorize, it is a guide to know what to do, when to do it, and why it matters.","translationKey":"doc:oceanic_guide","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"documentation, procedures, oceanic","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"Oceanic Guide, Learn to Fly the Atlantic on IVAO","subtitle":"This guide walks you step by step through a realistic oceanic flight on the IVAO network, from planning to oceanic exit.

Each phase includes

* a short explanation
* a checklist
* a phraseology example
* common mistakes
* a quiz

Do not rush, practice the radio lines out loud.","id":"SectionIntro_0014"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_0015"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Oceanic is procedural and predictable","id":"PhaseIntro_0017"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"Before anything else, you must understand what changes in an oceanic flight.

### What is different from a normal flight

In oceanic airspace

* continuous radar coverage does not exist
* ATC relies on planning and position reports
* poor preparation is the most common mistake

Everything is based on predictability.","id":"Text_0018"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0019"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Initial checklist","items":["Valid oceanic route","Defined oceanic entry and exit points","Appropriate flight level and Mach","Ability to comply with position reports"],"hint":"If you cannot confirm all items, you are not ready to file the flight plan.","id":"Checklist_0020"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0021"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Keep it predictable","body":"Oceanic flying rewards pilots who stay consistent with route, level, and timing. The goal is to be easy to separate.","id":"Callout_0022"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0023"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"What is the main goal of oceanic procedures","options":["To fly faster than normal","To make the flight predictable for procedural separation","To avoid talking to ATC"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"In oceanic airspace, predictability enables procedural separation when radar coverage is limited.","id":"QuizSingle_0024"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0025"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 1 recap","bullets":["Oceanic is procedural and predictable","Planning and reporting matter more than improvisation"],"id":"Summary_0026"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Oceanic is procedural and predictable
- Planning and reporting matter more than improvisation","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0027"}}],"phase":"Phase 1","title":"Before the flight","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0016","anchorId":"phase-5-before-the-flight","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0028"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Choose NAT Track or Random Route","id":"PhaseIntro_0030"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"Now you plan the flight in a concrete way.

### Two routing styles

#### NAT Track

* used for organized traffic flows
* identified by a letter
* clearance references track letter, level, and Mach

#### Random Route

* offers more flexibility
* clearance includes the full route
* you read back the route details

Both methods are valid on IVAO.","id":"Text_0031"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0032"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Planning checklist","items":["Route uses logical waypoints and geography","No unnecessary level changes","Mach plan is realistic and stable","Entry and exit points match the intended oceanic crossing"],"hint":"ATC expects logic, not creativity.","id":"Checklist_0033"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0034"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common planning pitfalls","body":"Avoid random points that do not follow geography, and avoid planning frequent level changes inside oceanic airspace.","id":"Callout_0035"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0036"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"Which planning choice improves oceanic realism and ATC handling","options":["Frequent level changes to chase winds","A stable Mach and a logical waypoint sequence","Silence on the radio unless contacted"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Stable Mach and logical routing reduce uncertainty and help procedural separation.","id":"QuizSingle_0037"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0038"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 2 recap","bullets":["Choose NAT Track or Random Route","Keep routing and Mach stable and logical"],"id":"Summary_0039"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Choose NAT Track or Random Route
- Keep routing and Mach stable and logical","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0040"}}],"phase":"Phase 2","title":"Planning and flight plan","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0029","anchorId":"phase-7-planning-and-flight-plan","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0041"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Request early","id":"PhaseIntro_0043"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"You are approaching oceanic airspace.

### When to request

Request oceanic clearance in advance, ideally around 40 minutes before the oceanic entry point.

Late requests are a common cause of delays.","id":"Text_0044"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0045"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"success","title":"What to include in your request","body":"* callsign
* oceanic entry point and ETO
* requested flight level at entry
* requested Mach
* route from the entry point, including track when applicable","id":"Callout_0046"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0047"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example, Oceanic Clearance request","language":"text","code":"Santa Maria Radio, TAP123
Request oceanic clearance
Estimating DOGAL at 2135
Request FL350, Mach decimal 78","id":"CodeBlock_0048"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0049"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common mistakes","body":"* forgetting Mach
* incorrect ETO
* unrealistic flight level request","id":"Callout_0050"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0051"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"You are about 30 minutes from the oceanic entry point and you have not requested clearance yet, what should you do","options":["Enter oceanic airspace and request later","Request the clearance now","Skip the request and continue on flight plan"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Requesting in advance reduces delay risk and allows coordination.","id":"QuizSingle_0052"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0053"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 3 recap","bullets":["Request early","Include entry point, ETO, level, Mach, and route"],"id":"Summary_0054"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Request early
- Include entry point, ETO, level, Mach, and route","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0055"}}],"phase":"Phase 3","title":"Requesting Oceanic Clearance","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0042","anchorId":"phase-9-requesting-oceanic-clearance","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0056"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Read back track, level, and Mach accurately","id":"PhaseIntro_0058"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"ATC will issue the clearance.

### The clearance may include

* authorized route or NAT Track
* flight level
* authorized Mach
* validity point or time

All elements must be correctly understood.","id":"Text_0059"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0060"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example, correct readback for a NAT Track","language":"text","code":"Cleared via NAT Track Alpha
Maintain FL350
Mach decimal 78
TAP123","id":"CodeBlock_0061"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0062"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"If unclear, ask","body":"If anything is unclear, ask for repetition. Never assume in oceanic airspace.","id":"Callout_0063"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0064"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"If you did not fully understand a clearance item, what is the best action","options":["Assume what makes sense and continue","Ask ATC to repeat or clarify","Wait silently and hope it resolves"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Clarification prevents errors, and keeps the flight predictable for separation.","id":"QuizSingle_0065"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0066"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 4 recap","bullets":["Read back track, level, and Mach accurately","Ask for clarification when needed"],"id":"Summary_0067"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Read back track, level, and Mach accurately
- Ask for clarification when needed","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0068"}}],"phase":"Phase 4","title":"Receiving and confirming the clearance","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0057","anchorId":"phase-11-receiving-and-confirming-the-clearance","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0069"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Report position with UTC time and next estimate","id":"PhaseIntro_0071"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"You have entered oceanic airspace, precision matters most here.

### Position reports normally include

* current position
* time in UTC
* next position
* estimated time at next position
* level and Mach if requested","id":"Text_0072"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0073"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example, position report","language":"text","code":"Santa Maria Radio, TAP123
Position 52 North 020 West at 2200
Next 53 North 030 West at 2300","id":"CodeBlock_0074"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0075"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"CPDLC and ADS C reminder","body":"Not all reports are automatic, ATC may request voice reports, radio remains mandatory as backup. Silence is never authorization.","id":"Callout_0076"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0077"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"Which item is essential in a standard position report","options":["Cabin temperature","Current position and time in UTC","Passenger count"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Position and UTC time are core for procedural separation and timing.","id":"QuizSingle_0078"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0079"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 5 recap","bullets":["Report position with UTC time and next estimate","Keep communication active, even with data link"],"id":"Summary_0080"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Report position with UTC time and next estimate
- Keep communication active, even with data link","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0081"}}],"phase":"Phase 5","title":"Inside oceanic airspace","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0070","anchorId":"phase-13-inside-oceanic-airspace","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0082"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Keep what is cleared","id":"PhaseIntro_0084"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"Not everything goes as planned, use predictable actions.

### General contingency principles

* maintain cleared level and Mach
* follow the cleared route
* do not improvise

Predictability keeps aircraft separated.","id":"Text_0085"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0086"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"You lose communications after entering oceanic airspace, what should you do","options":["Change level to avoid traffic","Continue according to last clearance","Reverse route immediately"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Maintaining the last clearance preserves predictability and procedural separation.","id":"QuizSingle_0087"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0088"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 6 recap","bullets":["Keep what is cleared","Avoid independent changes"],"id":"Summary_0089"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Keep what is cleared
- Avoid independent changes","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0090"}}],"phase":"Phase 6","title":"Abnormal situations","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0083","anchorId":"phase-15-abnormal-situations","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0091"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Transition cleanly to the next FIR","id":"PhaseIntro_0093"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"The crossing is almost complete.

### What happens next

* transition to a continental FIR
* frequency change
* possible new clearance

Remain focused until fully established in continental airspace.","id":"Text_0094"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0095"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Oceanic exit checklist","items":["Confirm your exit point and estimate","Be ready for a new frequency","Expect potential new clearance","Keep reporting as instructed until handed off"],"hint":"Do not relax early, the handoff matters.","id":"Checklist_0096"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0097"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Phase 7 recap","bullets":["Transition cleanly to the next FIR","Stay accurate until fully handed off"],"id":"Summary_0098"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"- Transition cleanly to the next FIR
- Stay accurate until fully handed off","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_0099"}}],"phase":"Phase 7","title":"Leaving oceanic airspace","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0092","anchorId":"phase-17-leaving-oceanic-airspace","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_0100"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"title":"","body":"Plan a flight from LPPT to KJFK.

1 Select a valid NAT Track
2 Choose an appropriate flight level and Mach
3 Write a complete oceanic clearance request
4 Define two position reports

If you can do this confidently, you are ready for oceanic operations on IVAO.","id":"Text_0102"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0103"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Conclusion","body":"Oceanic flying is not difficult, it is methodical. Pilots who plan well, communicate clearly, and respect the clearance, fly safely and smoothly.","id":"Callout_0104"}}],"phase":"Final","title":"Final challenge","subtitle":"","id":"PhaseCard_0101","anchorId":"phase-19-final-challenge","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","nextAnchor":"","nextTitle":""}}],"zones":{}}

title: Guia Oceanic
summary:
Este guia acompanha-te passo a passo num voo oceanic realista na rede IVAO, desde o planeamento até à saída do espaço oceanic.

Não é um rulebook para decorar, é um guia para saber o que fazer, quando fazer, e porque é importante.

### O que é diferente de um voo normal

Em oceanic airspace

* não existe cobertura radar contínua
* o ATC depende de planeamento e position reports
* a falta de preparação é o erro mais comum

Aqui, tudo gira à volta de previsibilidade.","id":"Text_0018"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0019"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Checklist inicial","items":["Rota oceanic válida","Pontos de entrada e saída oceanic definidos","Flight level e Mach adequados","Capacidade de cumprir position reports"],"hint":"Se não consegues confirmar tudo, ainda não estás pronto para submeter o flight plan.","id":"Checklist_0020"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0021"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Mantém previsível","body":"Voar em oceanic recompensa pilotos que mantêm consistência na rota, no level, e no timing. NAT Track

Ambos são válidos na IVAO.","id":"Text_0031"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0032"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Checklist de planeamento","items":["A rota usa waypoints lógicos e coerentes com a geografia","Sem mudanças de level desnecessárias","O plano de Mach é realista e estável","Pontos de entrada e saída condizem com a travessia oceanic"],"hint":"O ATC espera lógica, não criatividade.","id":"Checklist_0033"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0034"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Erros comuns no planeamento","body":"Evita pontos aleatórios que não seguem a geografia, e evita planear mudanças frequentes de level dentro de oceanic airspace.","id":"Callout_0035"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0036"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"Que escolha melhora o realismo oceanic e facilita o trabalho do ATC","options":["Mudanças frequentes de level para apanhar vento","Mach estável e sequência lógica de waypoints","Silêncio na rádio a não ser que o ATC chame"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Mach estável e routing lógico reduzem incerteza e ajudam a procedural separation.","id":"QuizSingle_0037"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"sm","id":"Spacer_0038"}},{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Resumo da Fase 2","bullets":["Escolhe NAT Track ou Random Route","Mantém routing e Mach estáveis e lógicos"],"id":"Summary_0039"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Escolhe NAT Track ou Random Route

title: First Flight on IVAO
summary:
This guide helps you complete your first flight on IVAO with confidence, from initial setup to parking at the gate.

You do not need to know everything, you only need to know the essentials to start correctly.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"first-flight-ivao","title":"First Flight on IVAO","summary":"This guide helps you complete your first flight on IVAO with confidence, from initial setup to parking at the gate.

You do not need to know everything, you only need to know the essentials to start correctly.","translationKey":"doc:first-flight-ivao","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"beginner, ivao, pilot, first flight","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"First Flight on IVAO","subtitle":"A practical guide for your first IVAO flight, from setup to shutdown.

Read calmly, follow the phases, and never hesitate to ask for help.","ctaLabel":"","ctaHref":"","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Overview","subtitle":"Follow the phases in order, just like a real flight.","readingTime":"6 min read","items":[{"label":"Phase 1","title":"Prepare your setup","anchor":"phase-1-setup","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Phase 2","title":"Install and connect","anchor":"phase-2-connect","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Phase 3","title":"Choose your first flight","anchor":"phase-3-flight","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Phase 4","title":"Plan and file the flight plan","anchor":"phase-4-plan","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Phase 5","title":"Communicating with ATC","anchor":"phase-5-atc","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"Phase 6","title":"Arrival and common issues","anchor":"phase-6-arrival","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Make sure everything works before connecting","id":"PhaseIntro_01"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Before your first flight, confirm that the basics work correctly.

You need

* a working flight simulator
* an active IVAO account
* a pilot client installed
* a functioning microphone

Do not continue if your audio is not working.","id":"Text_01"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Preparation checklist","items":["VID and password ready","Push to talk configured","Transponder working","Aircraft you already know"],"hint":"If something fails here, fix it before connecting to the network.","id":"Checklist_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Prepare everything before connecting
* Never test audio after you are online","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"phase":"Phase 1","title":"Prepare your setup","anchorId":"phase-1-setup","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Connect only when you are ready","id":"PhaseIntro_02"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Connect to the network only when you are fully ready to start.

Always connect cold and dark at a gate, never on the runway.

Before connecting, confirm

* flight plan filed
* route loaded in the aircraft
* radios prepared","id":"Text_02"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common mistake","body":"Connecting at the gate without a flight plan and asking ATC what to do.","id":"Callout_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Connect only when ready
* Planning comes before connection","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_02"}}],"phase":"Phase 2","title":"Install and connect","anchorId":"phase-2-connect","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0008"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"PhaseIntro","props":{"title":"Phase focus","body":"Keep everything simple","id":"PhaseIntro_03"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Your first IVAO flight should be short and easy to manage.

Recommendations

* 30 to 60 minutes
* same FIR
* simple aircraft
* familiar airports

Avoid events and long haul flights.","id":"Text_03"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Simple is better
* The goal is learning, not impressing","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_03"}}],"phase":"Phase 3","title":"Choose your first flight","anchorId":"phase-3-flight","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"You do not need perfect phraseology, you need clear communication.

Always say when you are new.

Example

Lisbon Ground, TAP123, first IVAO flight, request IFR clearance","id":"Text_04"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Tip","body":"ATC prefers an honest pilot over a silent pilot.","id":"Callout_02"}}],"phase":"Phase 4","title":"Communicating with ATC","anchorId":"phase-5-atc","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0010"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"If something goes wrong, stop and ask.

Useful phrases

Unable STAR, request vectors

Unsure position, request progressive taxi","id":"Text_05"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"What should you do if you do not understand an ATC instruction","options":["Ignore it and continue","Ask for clarification","Wait silently"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Asking for clarification prevents errors and reduces stress.","id":"Quiz_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"success","title":"Conclusion","body":"Your first IVAO flight is not a test, it is a beginning. Keep it simple, communicate clearly, and learn calmly.","id":"Callout_03"}}],"phase":"Phase 5","title":"Arrival and common issues","anchorId":"phase-6-arrival","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0011"}}],"zones":{}}

title: IVAO Phraseology for Beginners
summary: Reusable phraseology templates for your first flights on IVAO, organized by flight phase, including who to call, what to say, and what to read back.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"ivao-phraseology-beginners","title":"IVAO Phraseology for Beginners","summary":"Reusable phraseology templates for your first flights on IVAO, organized by flight phase, including who to call, what to say, and what to read back.","translationKey":"doc:ivao_phraseology_beginners","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"phraseology, beginner, pilot, rtf","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"IVAO Phraseology for Beginners","subtitle":"Copy, adapt, and speak clearly.

This page is a template library, not a local procedures document.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"SectionIntro","props":{"title":"Who to contact, the simple rule","body":"Call the lowest relevant ATC position first.

Typical IFR order

* Delivery, or Ground if no Delivery
* Ground
* Tower
* Departure, or Approach
* Center

If a position is not online, contact the next one that is online.

If no ATC is online, use UNICOM and standard procedures.","id":"SectionIntro_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Templates index","subtitle":"Jump to a phase and copy a template.","readingTime":"8 min read","items":[{"label":"Start","title":"Startup and pushback","anchor":"ph-startup","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Taxi","title":"Taxi out","anchor":"ph-taxiout","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Takeoff","title":"Line up and takeoff","anchor":"ph-takeoff","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Climb","title":"Departure and climb","anchor":"ph-departure","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Enroute","title":"Enroute basics","anchor":"ph-enroute","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"Arrival","title":"Approach and STAR, vectors","anchor":"ph-arrival","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}},{"label":"Landing","title":"Landing and vacating","anchor":"ph-landing","props":{"id":"Block_0007"}},{"label":"Taxi in","title":"Taxi to stand","anchor":"ph-taxiin","props":{"id":"Block_0008"}},{"label":"Non routine","title":"Unable, lost, radio issues","anchor":"ph-nonroutine","props":{"id":"Block_0009"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Start","title":"Startup and pushback","anchorId":"ph-startup","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Use this when you need engine start approval or pushback approval, depending on the airport.

If ATIS exists, include information letter.","id":"Text_Startup_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request startup","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, TAP123, stand 142, information Alpha
Request start up","id":"Code_Startup_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request pushback","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, TAP123, stand 142
Request pushback","id":"Code_Startup_02"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Readback reminder","body":"Read back anything that affects safety, such as runway, hold short, heading, altitude, squawk, and clearances.","id":"Callout_Startup_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Startup"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Taxi","title":"Taxi out","anchorId":"ph-taxiout","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request taxi, if you already have IFR clearance","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, TAP123
Request taxi","id":"Code_TaxiOut_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request taxi, if you do not have clearance yet","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, TAP123, stand 142, IFR to Porto, information Alpha
Request taxi","id":"Code_TaxiOut_02"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common taxi mistake","body":"Moving without an explicit taxi clearance, or crossing a runway without clearance.","id":"Callout_TaxiOut_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_TaxiOut"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Takeoff","title":"Line up and takeoff","anchorId":"ph-takeoff","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Ready for departure","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, TAP123, ready for departure runway 02","id":"Code_Takeoff_01"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"If instructed LINE UP AND WAIT, read it back and do not take off until you hear CLEARED FOR TAKE OFF.","id":"Text_Takeoff_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Takeoff"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Climb","title":"Departure and climb","anchorId":"ph-departure","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"First call after handoff","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Departure, TAP123, passing 2000 feet, climbing 5000 feet","id":"Code_Departure_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"If you cannot comply","language":"text","code":"Unable climb due performance, request maintain 5000 feet","id":"Code_Departure_02"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Departure"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Enroute","title":"Enroute basics","anchorId":"ph-enroute","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Most enroute flying is simple, maintain assigned level, speed, and route.

If you are cleared DIRECT, confirm the waypoint and then proceed.","id":"Text_Enroute_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Confirm direct clearance","language":"text","code":"Direct ODLIX, TAP123","id":"Code_Enroute_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Enroute"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Arrival","title":"Approach and STAR, vectors","anchorId":"ph-arrival","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Approach initial call","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Approach, TAP123, FL110, inbound, information Bravo","id":"Code_Arrival_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request vectors","language":"text","code":"Unable STAR, request vectors","id":"Code_Arrival_02"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Beginner friendly","body":"Vectors are normal and acceptable, especially on your first flights.","id":"Callout_Arrival_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Arrival"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Landing","title":"Landing and vacating","anchorId":"ph-landing","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"After landing, vacate when safe, then report runway vacated if required and switch frequency when instructed.","id":"Text_Landing_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Runway vacated","language":"text","code":"TAP123, runway vacated","id":"Code_Landing_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_Landing"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Taxi in","title":"Taxi to stand","anchorId":"ph-taxiin","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Taxi to stand request","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, TAP123, runway vacated
Request taxi to stand","id":"Code_TaxiIn_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_TaxiIn"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Non routine","title":"Unable, lost, radio issues","anchorId":"ph-nonroutine","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Ask to repeat","language":"text","code":"Say again for TAP123","id":"Code_NonRoutine_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Lost on taxi, ask progressive","language":"text","code":"TAP123, unsure position, request progressive taxi","id":"Code_NonRoutine_02"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Voice issue, use text","language":"text","code":"TAP123, radio issue, receiving only, can reply via text","id":"Code_NonRoutine_03"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"If you do not understand an instruction, what is best","options":["Guess and continue","Ask for clarification","Stay silent"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Clarification prevents errors and keeps traffic predictable.","id":"Quiz_NonRoutine_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_NonRoutine"}}],"zones":{}}

title: Flight Plan for Beginners
summary: A practical guide to filling out a flight plan correctly, field by field, with IFR and VFR examples, useful remarks, common mistakes, and short quizzes.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"flight-plan-for-beginners","title":"Flight Plan for Beginners","summary":"A practical guide to filling out a flight plan correctly, field by field, with IFR and VFR examples, useful remarks, common mistakes, and short quizzes.","translationKey":"doc:flight_plan_for_beginners","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"beginner, flight plan, ifr, vfr, procedures","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"Flight Plan for Beginners","subtitle":"Fill it correctly, fly with less stress.

A clear flight plan helps ATC help you.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Contents","subtitle":"Follow the order and use the examples to copy and adapt.","readingTime":"8 min read","items":[{"label":"Part 1","title":"Before you start","anchor":"fp-essentials","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Part 2","title":"IFR fields, step by step","anchor":"fp-ifr-fields","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Part 3","title":"VFR fields, step by step","anchor":"fp-vfr-fields","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Part 4","title":"Useful remarks","anchor":"fp-remarks","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Part 5","title":"Common mistakes","anchor":"fp-common-mistakes","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"Part 6","title":"Mini quizzes","anchor":"fp-quizzes","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Before opening the flight plan form, decide these five items

* IFR or VFR
* departure and destination aerodromes
* a basic route, at least first and last fixes
* a realistic cruise level or altitude
* an alternate, especially for IFR

If you do not have this, the flight plan will be confusing and ATC will have to guess.","id":"Text_Essentials_01"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Quick checklist","items":["I have a basic route, even if simple","I know my intended cruise level or altitude","I have a reasonable alternate","I know if I need help and will state it in remarks"],"hint":"Simple planning is better than complex and incorrect planning.","id":"Checklist_Essentials_01"}}],"phase":"Part 1","title":"Before you start","anchorId":"fp-essentials","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Below is what you should fill in for an IFR flight plan, and why.

Field names may vary depending on the pilot client, but the content is the same.","id":"Text_IFR_Intro"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Beginner tip","body":"If you are unsure, choose the simplest option and state that you are a beginner in remarks.","id":"Callout_IFR_01"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Callsign

Use the same callsign you will use on the network, example TAP123.

Aircraft type

Use the ICAO aircraft designator, example A320, B738, C172.

Departure and destination

Use ICAO aerodrome codes, example LPPT and LPPR.

Route

A clear route using real waypoints and airways when applicable.

Cruise level

A realistic level for distance and aircraft performance.

EOBT

Estimated off block time in UTC.

EET

Estimated total enroute time.

Alternate

A realistic alternate aerodrome.

Remarks

Use for short, useful information only.","id":"Text_IFR_FieldByField"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Complete IFR example, short and clean","language":"text","code":"Callsign: TAP123
Aircraft: A320
Rules: IFR
From: LPPT
To: LPPR
Route: SID DCT VOR DCT STAR
Cruise: FL340
Alternate: LPFR
Remarks: First IVAO flight, request simple instructions","id":"Code_IFR_Example_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"What to avoid in Route","body":"Avoid random points without logic and avoid routes you cannot explain.","id":"Callout_IFR_02"}}],"phase":"Part 2","title":"IFR fields, step by step","anchorId":"fp-ifr-fields","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0008"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"VFR flight plans focus on intention, altitude, and reporting points.

The goal is to tell ATC what you want to do, not to list airways.","id":"Text_VFR_Intro"}},{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Callsign

Example CSX123 or your general aviation callsign.

Aircraft type

Example C172.

Departure and destination

ICAO aerodromes or local fields if applicable.

Route

Include reporting points, coastline, or visual references.

Cruise altitude

A realistic VFR altitude.

EOBT and EET

Always in UTC.

Remarks

Use to request transit or describe training intentions.","id":"Text_VFR_FieldByField"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"VFR example with clear intention","language":"text","code":"Callsign: CSX123
Aircraft: C172
Rules: VFR
From: LPPT
To: LPCS
Route: VFR via reporting points, coastal
Cruise: 2500 ft
EET: 00:45
Remarks: Request VFR transit, first IVAO flight","id":"Code_VFR_Example_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"VFR needs context","body":"If you plan circuits, training, or sightseeing, state it clearly.","id":"Callout_VFR_01"}}],"phase":"Part 3","title":"VFR fields, step by step","anchorId":"fp-vfr-fields","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Remarks must be short and useful.

Good examples

* First IVAO flight, request simple instructions
* Request vectors on arrival
* Unable RNAV, request ILS
* Training flight
* VFR transit request

Avoid

* long paragraphs
* jokes or irrelevant text
* instructions to ATC","id":"Text_Remarks_01"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Remarks checklist","items":["It is short","It helps ATC help me","It is not a story","It is accurate and achievable"],"hint":"If it matters for ATC, it belongs in remarks.","id":"Checklist_Remarks_01"}}],"phase":"Part 4","title":"Useful remarks","anchorId":"fp-remarks","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0010"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Summary","props":{"title":"Top mistakes","bullets":["Callsign different from the one used in the pilot client","Incorrect or non ICAO aircraft type","Illogical or impossible route","Unrealistic cruise level","EOBT entered in local time instead of UTC","Remarks that are too long"],"id":"Summary_Mistakes_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Most disruptive mistake","body":"EOBT entered in local time, this breaks coordination and planning.","id":"Callout_Mistakes_01"}}],"phase":"Part 5","title":"Common mistakes","anchorId":"fp-common-mistakes","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","id":"PhaseCard_0011"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_07"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"What is the best use of remarks","options":["Writing a long explanation of the entire route","Adding short information that helps ATC provide an appropriate service","Giving instructions to ATC"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Remarks exist to provide short, useful context and limitations.","id":"Quiz_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"In which format must EOBT be entered","options":["Local time","UTC","Any format"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"EOBT must always be in UTC for consistency.","id":"Quiz_02"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"For a beginner IFR flight plan, what is the best approach to Route","options":["Use as many waypoints as possible to look realistic","Use a clear and simple route you can explain","Leave the route empty and let ATC decide"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Clear and logical routes reduce workload and surprises.","id":"Quiz_03"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Fill the essentials calmly
* Keep route and remarks simple and coherent
* Always use UTC and a consistent callsign","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"phase":"Part 6","title":"Mini quizzes","anchorId":"fp-quizzes","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0012"}}],"zones":{}}

title: IFR Basics in Practice
summary: A practical IFR guide focused on what you actually do in flight. Altitudes, headings, direct to, intercepts, simple holds, VNAV versus ALT, and how to correctly comply with ATC instructions.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"ifr-basics-in-practice-2","title":"IFR Basics in Practice","summary":"A practical IFR guide focused on what you actually do in flight. Altitudes, headings, direct to, intercepts, simple holds, VNAV versus ALT, and how to correctly comply with ATC instructions.","translationKey":"doc:ifr_basics_in_practice","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"beginner, ifr, basics, phraseology, procedures","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"IFR Basics in Practice","subtitle":"What ATC expects you to fly, and how to fly it correctly.

This guide focuses on practical execution, not theory.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Topics covered","subtitle":"Read in order, each part builds on the previous one.","readingTime":"10 min read","items":[{"label":"Part 1","title":"Altitudes and levels","anchor":"ifr-altitudes","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Part 2","title":"Headings and vectors","anchor":"ifr-headings","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Part 3","title":"Direct to and intercept","anchor":"ifr-direct-intercept","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Part 4","title":"Simple holds","anchor":"ifr-holds","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Part 5","title":"VNAV versus ALT","anchor":"ifr-vnav-alt","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"Part 6","title":"Complying with ATC instructions","anchor":"ifr-comply","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 1","title":"Altitudes and levels","anchorId":"ifr-altitudes","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"In IFR, altitude discipline is critical.

Below the transition altitude, you fly altitudes.
Above the transition altitude, you fly flight levels.

You must never choose your own altitude unless explicitly instructed.","id":"Text_Alt_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Golden rule","body":"Fly exactly the altitude or level you were cleared to, not what you think makes sense.","id":"Callout_Alt_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"ATC clears you to climb FL120, what do you do","options":["Climb to FL120 and level off","Climb to FL140 because it is smoother","Stop climbing when you feel comfortable"],"correctIndex":0,"explanation":"You must always comply with the cleared level exactly.","id":"Quiz_Alt_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 2","title":"Headings and vectors","anchorId":"ifr-headings","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"When ATC gives you a heading, you must fly that heading immediately.

A heading instruction cancels your own navigation until further notice.","id":"Text_Heading_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example phraseology","language":"text","code":"Turn left heading 270
Maintain 4000 feet","id":"Code_Heading_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common mistake","body":"Do not continue following the FMS route when you are on vectors.","id":"Callout_Heading_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0008"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 3","title":"Direct to and intercept","anchorId":"ifr-direct-intercept","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"A direct to clears you to navigate straight to a fix.

An intercept requires you to capture a course or radial.","id":"Text_Direct_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example phraseology","language":"text","code":"Proceed direct to DOGAL
Intercept the localizer runway 21","id":"Code_Direct_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"After being cleared direct to a fix, what should you do","options":["Turn immediately toward the fix","Wait until reaching your next waypoint","Ask ATC to confirm again"],"correctIndex":0,"explanation":"Direct to means immediate navigation unless restricted.","id":"Quiz_Direct_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 4","title":"Simple holds","anchorId":"ifr-holds","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"false","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"A hold keeps you in a protected area until further clearance.

For beginners, focus on entering safely and maintaining altitude and speed.","id":"Text_Hold_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Beginner advice","body":"If you are unsure, fly a simple entry and tell ATC you are established.","id":"Callout_Hold_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0010"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 5","title":"VNAV versus ALT","anchorId":"ifr-vnav-alt","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"VNAV manages vertical path, but ATC clears altitudes.

ALT mode must always protect the cleared altitude.","id":"Text_VNAV_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Critical rule","body":"Never descend or climb using VNAV unless you are cleared to do so.","id":"Callout_VNAV_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0011"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_07"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 6","title":"Complying with ATC instructions","anchorId":"ifr-comply","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"ATC instructions must be read back and flown as cleared.

If you cannot comply, say so immediately using the word unable.","id":"Text_Comply_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Correct phraseology","language":"text","code":"Unable climb due performance
Unable maintain speed","id":"Code_Comply_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Fly exactly what you are cleared
* Ask if unsure
* Say unable early, never guess","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0012"}}],"zones":{}}

title: VFR First Flight on IVAO
summary: A practical guide for your first VFR flight on IVAO. VFR rules, traffic circuits, reporting points, transponder use, correct phraseology, and knowing when to speak and when to stay silent.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"vfr-first-flight-ivao","title":"VFR First Flight on IVAO","summary":"A practical guide for your first VFR flight on IVAO. VFR rules, traffic circuits, reporting points, transponder use, correct phraseology, and knowing when to speak and when to stay silent.","translationKey":"doc:vfr_first_flight_ivao","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"beginner, vfr, phraseology, procedures","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"VFR First Flight on IVAO","subtitle":"Fly visually, communicate clearly, and keep it simple.

This guide is built for first time VFR pilots on the network.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Topics covered","subtitle":"Follow the flow of a typical VFR flight.","readingTime":"10 min read","items":[{"label":"Part 1","title":"VFR rules on IVAO","anchor":"vfr-rules","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Part 2","title":"Traffic circuits","anchor":"vfr-circuits","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Part 3","title":"Reporting points","anchor":"vfr-reporting-points","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Part 4","title":"Transponder use","anchor":"vfr-transponder","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Part 5","title":"VFR phraseology","anchor":"vfr-phraseology","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"Part 6","title":"When to talk and when to stay silent","anchor":"vfr-communication-discipline","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"VFR on IVAO follows real world principles.

You are responsible for terrain clearance, traffic avoidance, and staying within VFR limits.

ATC provides information and clearances when required, but does not fly the aircraft for you.","id":"Text_VFRRules_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Key principle","body":"VFR means you fly visually and request permission when entering controlled airspace.","id":"Callout_VFRRules_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"Who is responsible for terrain clearance during a VFR flight","options":["ATC","The pilot","The simulator"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"In VFR, the pilot is responsible for terrain and obstacle clearance.","id":"Quiz_VFRRules_01"}}],"phase":"Part 1","title":"VFR rules on IVAO","anchorId":"vfr-rules","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Traffic circuits are flown in a standard rectangular pattern.

Unless otherwise instructed, follow the published circuit direction and altitude.","id":"Text_Circuits_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Circuit reporting example","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, CSX123
Downwind runway 03, touch and go","id":"Code_Circuits_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Common mistake","body":"Do not join the circuit without clearance at controlled aerodromes.","id":"Callout_Circuits_01"}}],"phase":"Part 2","title":"Traffic circuits","anchorId":"vfr-circuits","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0008"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Reporting points are predefined visual locations used to manage VFR traffic.

Always report exactly the point you were cleared to report.","id":"Text_Reporting_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Reporting point phraseology","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, CSX123
Reporting Sierra at 1500 feet","id":"Code_Reporting_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"When should you report a reporting point","options":["When approaching it","When overhead the point","After passing it"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Reporting points are normally reported when overhead unless otherwise instructed.","id":"Quiz_Reporting_01"}}],"phase":"Part 3","title":"Reporting points","anchorId":"vfr-reporting-points","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"The transponder helps ATC identify and track your aircraft.

Use the assigned squawk, and Mode C unless instructed otherwise.","id":"Text_Transponder_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Standard VFR squawk","body":"If not assigned, use 7000 unless local procedures state otherwise.","id":"Callout_Transponder_01"}}],"phase":"Part 4","title":"Transponder use","anchorId":"vfr-transponder","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0010"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"VFR phraseology should be short, clear, and intention based.

Avoid unnecessary words and long explanations.","id":"Text_Phraseology_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example requests","language":"text","code":"Request taxi for VFR departure
Request VFR zone transit
Request joining left downwind runway 21","id":"Code_Phraseology_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Avoid this","body":"Do not describe what you see out of the window unless requested.","id":"Callout_Phraseology_01"}}],"phase":"Part 5","title":"VFR phraseology","anchorId":"vfr-phraseology","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0011"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_07"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Good VFR pilots know when to transmit and when to listen.

Speak when requesting clearance, reporting a required point, or responding to ATC.

Stay silent when monitoring, flying the circuit, or waiting for instruction.","id":"Text_Comm_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"When should you remain silent on frequency","options":["While waiting for ATC to finish another instruction","When you have a clearance to read back","When entering controlled airspace"],"correctIndex":0,"explanation":"Good frequency discipline avoids congestion and missed instructions.","id":"Quiz_Comm_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Fly visually and responsibly
* Keep phraseology short and clear
* Listen more than you talk","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"phase":"Part 6","title":"When to talk and when to stay silent","anchorId":"vfr-communication-discipline","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0012"}}],"zones":{}}

title: VFR Phraseology, Complete Guide
summary: A complete and practical VFR phraseology guide for IVAO. From start up to shutdown, including taxi, departure, circuit work, zone transit, reporting points, overhead joins, and correct frequency discipline.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"vfr-phraseology-complete","title":"VFR Phraseology, Complete Guide","summary":"A complete and practical VFR phraseology guide for IVAO. From start up to shutdown, including taxi, departure, circuit work, zone transit, reporting points, overhead joins, and correct frequency discipline.","translationKey":"doc:vfr_phraseology_complete","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"vfr, phraseology, beginner, procedures","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"VFR Phraseology, Complete Guide","subtitle":"Say the right thing, at the right time, and nothing more.

This guide follows a full VFR flight from engine start to shutdown.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Flight flow","subtitle":"Use this page as a reference before and during flight.","readingTime":"12 min read","items":[{"label":"1","title":"Start up and information","anchor":"vfr-startup","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"2","title":"Taxi","anchor":"vfr-taxi","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"3","title":"Departure","anchor":"vfr-departure","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"4","title":"Traffic circuit","anchor":"vfr-circuit","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"5","title":"Zone transit","anchor":"vfr-zone-transit","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}},{"label":"6","title":"Reporting points","anchor":"vfr-reporting-points","props":{"id":"Block_0006"}},{"label":"7","title":"Overhead join","anchor":"vfr-overhead-join","props":{"id":"Block_0007"}},{"label":"8","title":"Shutdown","anchor":"vfr-shutdown","props":{"id":"Block_0008"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Before engine start, you must have ATIS or aerodrome information.

At controlled aerodromes, request start up if required.","id":"Text_Startup_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Example phraseology","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, CSX123
Request start up, information Alpha","id":"Code_Startup_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Good practice","body":"Always state the ATIS letter when available.","id":"Callout_Startup_01"}}],"phase":"1","title":"Start up and information","anchorId":"vfr-startup","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Taxi clearance is required at controlled aerodromes.

Listen carefully and read back runway and holding point instructions.","id":"Text_Taxi_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Taxi request","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, CSX123
Request taxi for VFR departure","id":"Code_Taxi_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Readback example","language":"text","code":"Taxi holding point runway 21 via Alpha, CSX123","id":"Code_Taxi_02"}}],"phase":"2","title":"Taxi","anchorId":"vfr-taxi","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0010"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"For departure, ATC needs to know your intentions.

After takeoff, remain within instructions and altitude limits.","id":"Text_Departure_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Ready for departure","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, CSX123
Ready for departure runway 21","id":"Code_Departure_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Do not rush","body":"Wait for takeoff clearance, never line up without permission unless instructed.","id":"Callout_Departure_01"}}],"phase":"3","title":"Departure","anchorId":"vfr-departure","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0011"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"In the circuit, position reports keep traffic predictable.

Use standard legs and do not improvise.","id":"Text_Circuit_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Circuit report","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, CSX123
Left downwind runway 21, touch and go","id":"Code_Circuit_01"}}],"phase":"4","title":"Traffic circuit","anchorId":"vfr-circuit","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0012"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"To cross controlled airspace, you must request a VFR zone transit.

Be clear, short, and ready to accept conditions.","id":"Text_Transit_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Zone transit request","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Approach, CSX123
Request VFR zone transit from south to north at 2000 feet","id":"Code_Transit_01"}}],"phase":"5","title":"Zone transit","anchorId":"vfr-zone-transit","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0013"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_07"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Reporting points are used to sequence and separate VFR traffic.

Report exactly as instructed, when overhead.","id":"Text_Reporting_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Reporting point call","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Tower, CSX123
Reporting Sierra at 1500 feet","id":"Code_Reporting_01"}}],"phase":"6","title":"Reporting points","anchorId":"vfr-reporting-points","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0014"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_08"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"An overhead join is commonly used at uncontrolled or lightly controlled aerodromes.

Always request before joining overhead.","id":"Text_Overhead_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Overhead join request","language":"text","code":"Cascais Tower, CSX123
Request overhead join runway 17","id":"Code_Overhead_01"}}],"phase":"7","title":"Overhead join","anchorId":"vfr-overhead-join","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0015"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_09"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"After landing and taxi, advise ATC when parking and shutting down.","id":"Text_Shutdown_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Shutdown call","language":"text","code":"Lisbon Ground, CSX123
On stand, shutting down","id":"Code_Shutdown_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Keep calls short and clear
* State intention first
* Listen before transmitting
* Silence is also good discipline","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"phase":"8","title":"Shutdown","anchorId":"vfr-shutdown","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0016"}}],"zones":{}}

title: Readback and Acknowledgement
summary: A focused guide on what must be read back to ATC, what can be acknowledged only, with correct and incorrect examples and quick quizzes to build good radio discipline.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"readback-and-acknowledgement","title":"Readback and Acknowledgement","summary":"A focused guide on what must be read back to ATC, what can be acknowledged only, with correct and incorrect examples and quick quizzes to build good radio discipline.","translationKey":"doc:readback_acknowledgement","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"phraseology, readback, radio, beginner, procedures","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"Readback and Acknowledgement","subtitle":"Knowing what to read back is as important as knowing what to say.

This guide helps you avoid the most common radio mistakes.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Topics covered","subtitle":"Short, practical, and directly applicable.","readingTime":"6 min read","items":[{"label":"Part 1","title":"What must be read back","anchor":"rb-mandatory","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Part 2","title":"What can be acknowledged","anchor":"rb-ack","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Part 3","title":"Correct and incorrect examples","anchor":"rb-examples","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Part 4","title":"Quick quizzes","anchor":"rb-quizzes","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Certain ATC instructions must always be read back in full.

These items affect safety and separation.","id":"Text_Mandatory_01"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Mandatory readback items","items":["Runway assignments","Clearances to takeoff or land","Taxi instructions with holding points or runway crossings","Altitudes and flight levels","Headings","Speeds","SSR codes","Approach clearances"],"hint":"If it affects where you go, how high you fly, or which runway you use, read it back.","id":"Checklist_Mandatory_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Golden rule","body":"When in doubt, read it back.","id":"Callout_Mandatory_01"}}],"phase":"Part 1","title":"What must be read back","anchorId":"rb-mandatory","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0005"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Some instructions do not require a full readback.

A simple acknowledgement is sufficient.","id":"Text_Ack_01"}},{"type":"Checklist","props":{"title":"Acknowledgement only","items":["Traffic information","Weather information","Frequency changes","Sequencing information","Wake turbulence advisories"],"hint":"Use your callsign with words like roger, copied, or wilco when appropriate.","id":"Checklist_Ack_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Avoid over reading","body":"Do not read back long traffic information unless requested.","id":"Callout_Ack_01"}}],"phase":"Part 2","title":"What can be acknowledged","anchorId":"rb-ack","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0006"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Altitude clearance","language":"text","code":"ATC: Climb to 5000 feet

Correct readback:
Climb 5000 feet, CSX123

Incorrect:
Roger, CSX123","id":"Code_Example_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Taxi clearance","language":"text","code":"ATC: Taxi holding point runway 21 via Alpha

Correct readback:
Taxi holding point runway 21 via Alpha, CSX123

Incorrect:
Taxiing, CSX123","id":"Code_Example_02"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Traffic information","language":"text","code":"ATC: Traffic is a Cessna on left base

Correct:
Traffic in sight, CSX123

Acceptable:
Copied, CSX123

Incorrect:
Cessna on left base, CSX123","id":"Code_Example_03"}}],"phase":"Part 3","title":"Correct and incorrect examples","anchorId":"rb-examples","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"body":[{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"Which instruction must always be read back","options":["Weather information","Climb to FL120","Traffic information"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Altitudes and flight levels always require a readback.","id":"Quiz_01"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"What is the correct response to a frequency change","options":["Read back the entire frequency","Roger and change frequency","Ignore the instruction"],"correctIndex":1,"explanation":"Frequency changes normally require acknowledgement, not a full readback.","id":"Quiz_02"}},{"type":"QuizSingle","props":{"question":"ATC says cleared to land runway 03, what is the correct response","options":["Cleared to land runway 03, CSX123","Landing now","Roger"],"correctIndex":0,"explanation":"Landing clearances must always be read back with the runway.","id":"Quiz_03"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Read back anything that affects safety
* Acknowledge information, do not repeat it
* When unsure, read it back","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"phase":"Part 4","title":"Quick quizzes","anchorId":"rb-quizzes","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","id":"PhaseCard_0008"}}],"zones":{}}

title: Unable and Useful Requests
summary: How and when to say unable, and how to make clear, useful requests to ATC. This guide covers common situations such as climb, speed, vectors, delay, level changes, and correct use of say again and stand by.
content:
{"root":{"props":{"slug":"unable-and-useful-requests","title":"Unable and Useful Requests","summary":"How and when to say unable, and how to make clear, useful requests to ATC. This guide covers common situations such as climb, speed, vectors, delay, level changes, and correct use of say again and stand by.","translationKey":"doc:unable_and_requests","categoryId":"377f3cb3-0dfd-4e44-aba3-2a29fcbe72f7","tags":"phraseology, unable, requests, radio, beginner","published":"true"}},"content":[{"type":"Hero","props":{"title":"Unable and Useful Requests","subtitle":"ATC cannot help you if you do not speak up.

Saying unable early prevents problems later.","imageUrl":"","id":"Hero_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"md","id":"Spacer_01"}},{"type":"PhaseOverview","props":{"title":"Topics covered","subtitle":"Simple words that make your flight safer and smoother.","readingTime":"7 min read","items":[{"label":"Part 1","title":"When and how to say unable","anchor":"unable-basics","props":{"id":"Block_0001"}},{"label":"Part 2","title":"Unable climb and unable speed","anchor":"unable-performance","props":{"id":"Block_0002"}},{"label":"Part 3","title":"Request vectors and request delay","anchor":"requests-vectors-delay","props":{"id":"Block_0003"}},{"label":"Part 4","title":"Request higher and request lower","anchor":"requests-level","props":{"id":"Block_0004"}},{"label":"Part 5","title":"Say again and stand by","anchor":"say-again-standby","props":{"id":"Block_0005"}}],"id":"PhaseOverview_01"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_02"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 1","title":"When and how to say unable","anchorId":"unable-basics","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Unable is used when you cannot comply with an ATC instruction.

It must be said immediately, clearly, and with the reason if possible.","id":"Text_Unable_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Basic structure","language":"text","code":"Unable [instruction] due [reason], [callsign]","id":"Code_Unable_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Do not delay","body":"Never attempt an instruction you cannot comply with. Say unable immediately.","id":"Callout_Unable_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0006"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_03"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 2","title":"Unable climb and unable speed","anchorId":"unable-performance","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Performance limitations are common, especially at high weight or altitude.

ATC needs to know early to adjust separation.","id":"Text_Performance_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Unable climb examples","language":"text","code":"Unable climb FL380 due performance, TAP123
Unable maintain climb rate, TAP123","id":"Code_UnableClimb_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Unable speed examples","language":"text","code":"Unable maintain 210 knots, TAP123
Unable reduce speed due configuration, TAP123","id":"Code_UnableSpeed_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0007"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_04"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 3","title":"Request vectors and request delay","anchorId":"requests-vectors-delay","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Requests help ATC adapt the plan to your situation.

Make requests early and clearly.","id":"Text_Requests_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request vectors","language":"text","code":"Request vectors for approach, TAP123
Request radar vectors to final, TAP123","id":"Code_Vectors_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Request delay","language":"text","code":"Request delay for checklist, TAP123
Request holding due workload, TAP123","id":"Code_Delay_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"info","title":"Better early than late","body":"Early requests are easier to accommodate.","id":"Callout_Requests_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0008"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_05"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 4","title":"Request higher and request lower","anchorId":"requests-level","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"You may request a different level for performance, weather, or comfort.

Do not change level without clearance.","id":"Text_Level_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Level change requests","language":"text","code":"Request higher, TAP123
Request lower due turbulence, TAP123","id":"Code_Level_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0009"}},{"type":"Spacer","props":{"size":"lg","id":"Spacer_06"}},{"type":"PhaseCard","props":{"phase":"Part 5","title":"Say again and stand by","anchorId":"say-again-standby","collapsible":"true","defaultOpen":"true","body":[{"type":"Text","props":{"body":"Say again and stand by are essential tools for radio discipline.

Use them correctly to avoid mistakes.","id":"Text_SayAgain_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Say again","language":"text","code":"Say again, TAP123
Say again last instruction, TAP123","id":"Code_SayAgain_01"}},{"type":"CodeBlock","props":{"title":"Stand by","language":"text","code":"Stand by, TAP123","id":"Code_StandBy_01"}},{"type":"Callout","props":{"variant":"warning","title":"Important","body":"Do not use stand by to delay compliance. It only means you will respond shortly.","id":"Callout_SayAgain_01"}},{"type":"KeyTakeaway","props":{"title":"Key takeaway","body":"* Say unable early and clearly
* Make requests before problems escalate
* Never change altitude or speed without clearance","tone":"primary","id":"KeyTakeaway_01"}}],"id":"PhaseCard_0010"}}],"zones":{}}
